thread.title: Hairopoulos: Why beating a struggling Texas team still resonates for OU
thread.title_full: Hairopoulos: Why beating a struggling Texas team still resonates for OU | Dallas Morning News

author: Kate Hairopoulos
title: Hairopoulos: Why beating a struggling Texas team still resonates for OU
text:
If No. 10 Oklahoma takes down Texas on Saturday at the Cotton Bowl, as expected, it won't necessarily elevate the Sooners in the national discussion.
That's one of the downsides to the 1-4 Longhorns being so down.
But a rivalry victory amid the deep-fried spectacle of State Fair of Texas would be another step in OU cementing its role as legit Big 12 competition to No. 2 TCU and No. 3 Baylor -- which would be helpful to the league -- and in rebounding from last season's 8-5 flop.
"The chip is still there, it's not going anywhere [any] time soon," said cornerback Zack Sanchez, of Keller Central. "We still have a lot of improvement left to make as a defense and as a team. ... It's just a mentality this team has."
OU started the season ranked No. 19 but wins over then-ranked Tennessee and West Virginia have moved it into the top 10. Of course, OU started last season ranked No. 4 before plummeting. The Sooners did hold on to beat Texas, 31-26, before the crash continued in earnest.
"We have to be cognizant of the tendency to let up and start looking at the rankings and looking at the stats and say 'hey, we're doing pretty good,'" said senior center Ty Darlington. "We've got so much room for improvement. ...That's been addressed. ...We're not going to start feeling ourselves a little bit. We're hungry."
Coach Bob Stoops said his Sooners were unlikely to start feeling too good, as heavily favored as they may be in facing their Red River rival.
"We're not even five games into it," Stoops said. "We've got to really push to make our improvement. ...It shouldn't be hard to remind them of what's been said about them for the last year. If they have any sense at all, they'll understand that. ...We haven't done anything yet."
OU can beat Texas for the fifth time in six games. This is the third straight season that UT ventures into Fair Park unranked.
The Sooners have actually had a harder time of late with their Bedlam rivals, going 2-2 against Oklahoma State over the last four seasons.
After Saturday, the Sooners continue Big 12 play, but the brunt of the schedule is on the back end, with a trip to Baylor and hosting TCU leading into visiting Oklahoma State over the final three weeks of the season.
For now, OU has spent the week reminding itself that anything can happen against rivals -- including watching footage of OU's loss to Texas in 2013 when the Sooners were favored. And beating the Longhorns still resonates, the Sooners say, or at least is required to keep contending for OU's first outright Big 12 title since 2010.
"It's huge for us, whether it's [Oklahoma State] or Texas, it's a game we've got to win every year," Sanchez said. "Obviously the fans want us to win more than anything. For us, it's another Big 12 game, especially for what we're trying to accomplish this year; it's another game we've got to win."
